stem: The nurse is administering a rectal suppository. Place the actions in the correct order.

options.text: Insert the suppository past the internal anal sphincter (about 1 inch in children, 3-4 inches in adults).
Apply water-soluble lubricant to the rounded tip of the suppository.
Place the suppository against the rectal wall (not into the stool).
Instruct the client to remain side-lying for 5-10 minutes.
Position the client in the Left Sims position with the right leg flexed.

rationale.correct: Rectal administration ensures absorption via the rectal mucosa. (1) Left Sims facilitates access. (2) Lubrication prevents trauma. (3) Passing the internal sphincter prevents expulsion. (4) Contact with the wall (mucosa) is required for absorption; placing it into stool will delay or prevent the effect. (5) Positioning allows the medication to dissolve without leaking.
rationale.incorrect: Using an oil-based lubricant (like Vaseline) can interfere with the dissolution of the medication; use water-soluble only.
clinicalPearls: If the suppository is soft, it can be hardened by running it under cold water while still in the foil wrapper before administration.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that if the patient has stool in the rectum, you should try to guide the suppository *around* the fecal mass so it touches the pink mucosal wall.

reviewUnits.heading: Non-Parenteral Medication Administration
reviewUnits.body: Nurses monitor for potential bradycardia (Vagal pulse) and verify the 6 rights of medication administration.
